docs.snippet: The saga of the Cosmos-Chicago rivalry will continue this afternoon at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., when their game will decide the winner of the third annual Trans-Atlantic Challenge Cup.   Although the Cosmos have defeated Chicago by...
docs.lead_paragraph: The saga of the Cosmos-Chicago rivalry will continue this afternoon at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., when their game will decide the winner of the third annual Trans-Atlantic Challenge Cup. Although the Cosmos have defeated Chicago by 3-1 scores twice in the North American Soccer League this season, Chicago holds a 7-3 edge in the series that began in 1976, and the Sting won the Soccer Bowl last year.

docs.snippet: The State Department said today that the chief of the political section of the American Embassy in Montevideo had been declared persona non grata by the Uruguayan Government, accused of ''interfering with internal Uruguayan matters.''   No details of...
docs.lead_paragraph: The State Department said today that the chief of the political section of the American Embassy in Montevideo had been declared persona non grata by the Uruguayan Government, accused of ''interfering with internal Uruguayan matters.'' No details of the purported interference were immediately available, either from the military regime in Montevideo or from the State Department, although there were indications among Reagan Administration officials that the ouster was related to Britain's war with Argentina over the Falkland Islands.

headline.main: URUGUAY OUSTS U.S. EMBASSY'S POLITICAL AIDE

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: Around the World A2 Uruguay ousts U.S. Embassy aide A2 Colombians elect president as troops guard voting areas A3 In Soviet, success of peace campaign stirs its doubts A3 Moynihan calls for interim nuclear arms accord A3 British attack: Of a type ''not seen since World War II'' A4 At the British beachhead, cold nights and muddy days A4 Peru says U.S. must press Britain to resume talks A5 Issue of thousands missing since '70's lingers in Argentina A5 Haig and Mrs. Kirkpatrick said to argue over Falkland stand A5 Washington Talk Briefing A8 Decision File A8 White House: Clark emerges as a maker of policy A8 Head of O.A.S., an Argentine, sees public duty to be neutral A8 Congressional pages get an inside view of Capitol Hill A8 MEMORIAL DAY Parking - Sunday rules; alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation - No collections; no street cleaning. Federal, state and municipal offices - Closed. Post offices - Closed; special delivery and express-mail delivery only. Banks - Closed. Stock and commodity markets -Closed. Transportation - Long Island Rail Road and Conrail on holiday schedules; subways and buses on Sunday schedules. Libraries - Closed. Schools - Closed.

docs.snippet: The Chicago Sting captured the third Trans-Atlantic Challenge Cup today with a 4-3 victory over the Cosmos before a crowd of 36,904 at Giants Stadium.   Arno Steffenhagen scored two goals, and Karl-Heinz Granitza and Gordon Hill one apiece for...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Chicago Sting captured the third Trans-Atlantic Challenge Cup today with a 4-3 victory over the Cosmos before a crowd of 36,904 at Giants Stadium. Arno Steffenhagen scored two goals, and Karl-Heinz Granitza and Gordon Hill one apiece for Chicago. Giorgio Chinaglia scored all three goals for the Cosmos and had another nullified in the second half because he pushed off an opponent. Another Cosmos goal was disallowed because of an offside.

byline.original: By ALEX YANNIS, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: For nine months, Roberto Cabanas waited for his injured back to heal so that he could return to midfield for the Cosmos.
docs.lead_paragraph: For nine months, Roberto Cabanas waited for his injured back to heal so that he could return to midfield for the Cosmos.

docs.snippet: British forces have seized vital high ground about 10 miles west of Stanley, the capital of the Falkland Islands, after only moderate fighting, military sources said tonight.   The sources disclosed that paratroopers and Royal Marines had ousted...
docs.lead_paragraph: British forces have seized vital high ground about 10 miles west of Stanley, the capital of the Falkland Islands, after only moderate fighting, military sources said tonight. The sources disclosed that paratroopers and Royal Marines had ousted Argentine soldiers manning small outposts on the summits of 1,504-foot Mount Kent and adjacent hills, from which Stanley is clearly visible in good weather. The hills form a sharp ridge overlooking a featureless plain leading to the capital and would give the British valuable positions for observation and possibly for artillery. British control of the whole ridge would expose enemy forces, bottled up on a thin finger of land jutting into the South Atlantic, to 105-millimeter howitzer fire from one direction and 4.5-inch naval gunfire from the other.

headline.main: BRITAIN REPORTS SEIZING KEY HILLS OUTSIDE STANLEY

byline.original: By R.W. APPLE Jr., Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: The Uruguayan ejection of a senior American diplomat last week led to speculation that the increasingly warm relations between the Reagan Administration and Montevideo's heavily military Government might be cooling.   ''This falls like a bombshell,''...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Uruguayan ejection of a senior American diplomat last week led to speculation that the increasingly warm relations between the Reagan Administration and Montevideo's heavily military Government might be cooling. ''This falls like a bombshell,'' one American living here said of the move in which James C. Cason, chief of the embassy's political section, was declared persona non grata without a specific reason being given. His reaction suggested that the move might work to reverse the beneficial effects of visits by Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the chief American delegate to the United Nations, and a succession of top American generals.

headline.main: MOVE BY URUGUAY WORRIES U.S. AIDES

byline.original: By DOUGLAS MARTIN, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: Stanley, the remote South Atlantic settlement that has become the final prize in the battle for the Falkland Islands, seems an unlikely site for a colonial capital.   Little more than a village, the settlement, which has a peacetime population of...
docs.lead_paragraph: Stanley, the remote South Atlantic settlement that has become the final prize in the battle for the Falkland Islands, seems an unlikely site for a colonial capital. Little more than a village, the settlement, which has a peacetime population of just over 1,000 and is the only real town in the Falklands, is on a narrow strip of land on the east coast of East Falkland Island surrounded by some of the wettest and roughest terrain in the entire colony. But it has one key feature that made it an ideal site for a colonial port - a deep, almost landlocked harbor connected by a narrows to an even deeper semiprotected outer harbor known as Port William.

headline.main: A FINE HARBOR WON STANLEY ITS PLACE AS ISLANDS' CAPITAL

docs.snippet: The military high command said tonight that fighting in the Falkland Islands today was limited to artillery shelling between the British forces surrounding Stanley and the Argentine troops holding the capital.   The brief communique was the first...
docs.lead_paragraph: The military high command said tonight that fighting in the Falkland Islands today was limited to artillery shelling between the British forces surrounding Stanley and the Argentine troops holding the capital. The brief communique was the first word in 24 hours from the Argentine armed forces about any new military action in the Falklands, known here as the Malvinas. But various Argentine officials sought during the day to play down the decisiveness of the expected final battle for control of the islands. Brig. Gen. Basilio Lami Dozo, the commander of the air force and a member of the three-man junta that governs Argentina, said the battle ''is just that, a battle, and many battles are waged in a conflict.''

headline.main: ARGENTINE OFFICIALS ARE BELITTLING THE BATTLE FOR STANLEY

docs.snippet: The blood pressures of fans in more than 140 countries where soccer is the most popular sport will begin to rise next Sunday and remain elevated for 28 days. Their emotions will be charged by the World Cup tournament, which will be played in Spain at...
docs.lead_paragraph: The blood pressures of fans in more than 140 countries where soccer is the most popular sport will begin to rise next Sunday and remain elevated for 28 days. Their emotions will be charged by the World Cup tournament, which will be played in Spain at 16 stadiums in 14 cities, starting with a game in Barcelona between Argentina and Belgium, and ending July 11 with the final in Madrid. The final at Santiago Bernabeu Stadium will attract a worldwide television audience expected to be more than one billion. For the first time, there will be 52 matches because there are 24 countries participating, eight more than the previous 16. The tournament actually kicked off on March 26, 1980, with qualifying matches between Cyprus and Ireland, and Israel and Northern Ireland. In all, 106 countries took part. There were 306 games played to determine the 22 qualifiers who would join Argentina and Spain, the automatic qualifiers as the defending champion and the host, in the 12th tournament. Despite the war between Britain and Argentina over the Falkland Islands, Federation Internationale de Football Association, the governing body and organizer of the World Cup, has been assured that all the teams will participate.

headline.main: SOCCER'S BIGGEST EVENT: A LOOK AT THE WORLD CUP
